title: Hebrews Chapter 11 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Hebrews chapter 11 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Hebrews Chapter 11 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Hebrews Chapter 11.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 11:1, what is faith described as?
options: The substance of things hoped for
questions.correctAnswer: The substance of things hoped for
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:1 states that faith is the substance of things hoped for, and the evidence of things not seen.

questions.question: Who offered a more excellent sacrifice than Cain by faith according to Hebrews 11:4?
questions.correctAnswer: Abel
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:4 explains that by faith Abel offered unto God a more excellent sacrifice than Cain.

questions.question: True or False: Hebrews 11:6 says it is impossible to please God without faith.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:6 clearly states that without faith it is impossible to please God.

questions.question: By faith, who prepared an ark to save his household?
questions.correctAnswer: Noah
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:7 says that by faith Noah, being warned by God, prepared an ark to save his house.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 11:8, Abraham obeyed when he was called to go to a place he would later receive as his inheritance. What did he not know?
questions.correctAnswer: Where he was going
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:8 says Abraham went out not knowing whither he went.

questions.question: Through faith, what did Sarah receive strength to do when she was past age?
questions.correctAnswer: Conceive seed
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:11 states that Sarah received strength to conceive seed through faith.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Hebrews 11:10: 'For he looked for a city which hath ______, whose builder and maker is God.'
questions.correctAnswer: foundations
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:10 describes the city as having foundations whose builder and maker is God.

questions.question: By faith, who was translated so that he did not see death?
questions.correctAnswer: Enoch
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:5 says that by faith Enoch was translated so that he should not see death.

questions.question: True or False: Hebrews 11:15 says if the faithful had been mindful of the country they came from, they might have had the opportunity to return.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:15 states that if they had been mindful of their country, they could have returned.

questions.question: Who did Abraham offer up by faith when he was tried?
questions.correctAnswer: Isaac
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:17 explains that Abraham offered up Isaac by faith when he was tried.

questions.question: By faith, who blessed Jacob and Esau concerning things to come?
questions.correctAnswer: Isaac
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:20 states that by faith Isaac blessed Jacob and Esau.

questions.question: By faith, Moses refused to be called the son of whom?
questions.correctAnswer: Pharaoh's daughter
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:24 says Moses refused to be called the son of Pharaoh's daughter by faith.

questions.question: True or False: Hebrews 11:30 states that by faith the walls of Jericho fell down after they were compassed about seven days.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:30 confirms the walls of Jericho fell by faith after seven days of compassing.

questions.question: Who did the harlot Rahab protect by faith, according to Hebrews 11:31?
questions.correctAnswer: The spies
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:31 tells that Rahab did not perish because she received the spies with peace by faith.

questions.question: By faith, what did Moses keep to protect the Israelites from the destroyer?
options: The Passover and sprinkling of blood
questions.correctAnswer: The Passover and sprinkling of blood
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:28 states that by faith Moses kept the Passover and the sprinkling of blood to protect against the destroyer.

medium.title: Hebrews Chapter 11 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Hebrews Chapter 11 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with doubt about God's existence and His rewards. Based on Hebrews 11, what biblical truth would you share about faith?
options: Without faith it is impossible to please God because one must believe He exists and rewards those who seek Him diligently.
Faith is only necessary when facing physical danger, not for daily life.
God rewards people based on works, not faith.
Faith is primarily about seeing physical proof of God's presence.
questions.correctAnswer: Without faith it is impossible to please God because one must believe He exists and rewards those who seek Him diligently.
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:6 teaches that faith is essential to please God and that He rewards those who earnestly seek Him. This counsel encourages believers to trust in God's existence and His just rewards as foundational to faith.

questions.question: How does Hebrews 11 teach us about obedience to God's call through the example of Abraham?
options: Abraham obeyed and went out not knowing where he was going, trusting God's promise for his inheritance.
Abraham demanded clear instructions before moving.
Abraham waited until he had perfect understanding before obeying God's call.
Abraham only obeyed when others convinced him.
questions.correctAnswer: Abraham obeyed and went out not knowing where he was going, trusting God's promise for his inheritance.
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:8 shows Abraham's faith in obedience by leaving his home without knowing his destination, demonstrating trust in God's promises. This teaches believers to obey God even without full understanding.

questions.question: In a situation where a believer faces trials and persecution, what does Hebrews 11 encourage us to remember about the experiences of the faithful in the past?
options: Many endured mockings, imprisonments, and even death, yet maintained faith for a better resurrection.
Believers in the past never faced serious trials or persecution.
Trials are a punishment for lack of faith.
questions.correctAnswer: Many endured mockings, imprisonments, and even death, yet maintained faith for a better resurrection.
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:35-38 recounts the sufferings of faithful believers who endured great hardships but remained steadfast in faith, teaching modern believers perseverance and hope in eternal reward.

questions.question: A believer wonders how to develop trust in God’s promises despite not seeing them fulfilled yet. What insight does Hebrews 11 provide?
options: The faithful saw promises from afar and embraced them, acknowledging they were strangers and pilgrims on earth.
Faith depends only on visible, immediate results.
God's promises are always fulfilled instantly.
Unseen promises should not influence daily living.
questions.correctAnswer: The faithful saw promises from afar and embraced them, acknowledging they were strangers and pilgrims on earth.
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:13-16 describes how the faithful trusted God’s promises even without receiving them during their lifetime, encouraging believers to live with hope and perspective on their heavenly citizenship.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 11, how does faith impact our approach to family and parenting?
options: Sarah received strength to conceive a child past age because she judged God faithful to His promise.
Faith has no connection to family life or parenting.
Parents should rely on their own strength rather than trust God for family blessings.
Faith only matters in public ministry, not in private family matters.
questions.correctAnswer: Sarah received strength to conceive a child past age because she judged God faithful to His promise.
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:11 highlights Sarah’s faith in God’s promise resulting in the birth of Isaac, showing that trusting God is vital in family life and parenting even in challenging circumstances.

questions.question: What practical lesson about work ethic and integrity can we learn from Moses’ example in Hebrews 11?
options: Moses chose to suffer affliction with God’s people rather than enjoy sinful pleasures, valuing the reward of righteousness.
Moses sought personal gain over God’s will.
Moses ignored God’s calling to focus on worldly success.
Integrity is less important than comfort.
questions.correctAnswer: Moses chose to suffer affliction with God’s people rather than enjoy sinful pleasures, valuing the reward of righteousness.
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:24-26 shows Moses’ faith-driven choice to identify with God’s people and reject temporary sin’s pleasures, teaching the importance of integrity and perseverance in God’s work.

questions.question: A believer struggles with the fear of worldly opposition when serving God. What encouragement does Hebrews 11 provide?
options: By faith, Moses forsook Egypt without fearing the king’s wrath, seeing Him who is invisible.
Believers should avoid conflict and worldly opposition at all costs.
Fear is a sign of weak faith and should be ignored without prayer.
God’s protection depends on avoiding all risks.
questions.correctAnswer: By faith, Moses forsook Egypt without fearing the king’s wrath, seeing Him who is invisible.
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:27 encourages believers to trust God’s unseen presence and protection when facing opposition, helping overcome fear through faith.

questions.question: How does Hebrews 11 illustrate the importance of generosity and stewardship through the lives of the faithful?
options: Faithful individuals often sacrificed and obeyed God’s commands even when costly, like Noah building the ark to save his family.
Faithful living does not require material sacrifice or stewardship.
God’s blessings come only to those who keep their wealth.
questions.correctAnswer: Faithful individuals often sacrificed and obeyed God’s commands even when costly, like Noah building the ark to save his family.
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:7 shows Noah’s faith-led obedience in building the ark despite opposition and cost, highlighting faithful stewardship and sacrifice for God’s purposes.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged by delays in receiving God’s promises. How does Hebrews 11 counsel us about patience and hope in God’s timing?
options: The faithful died without receiving the promises but remained persuaded and embraced them, seeking a heavenly city.
God’s promises must be fulfilled immediately or they are not true.
Delayed promises mean God has forgotten us.
Impatience is a sign of strong faith.
questions.correctAnswer: The faithful died without receiving the promises but remained persuaded and embraced them, seeking a heavenly city.
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:13-16 teaches that faithful believers patiently trusted God’s promises despite not seeing fulfillment in their lifetime, encouraging hope beyond present circumstances.

questions.question: What does Hebrews 11 teach about humility and contentment through the example of the faithful described in the chapter?
options: They accepted being strangers and pilgrims on earth, showing contentment in God’s promises rather than worldly status.
They insisted on earthly riches and recognition.
Humility is not important if one has faith.
questions.correctAnswer: They accepted being strangers and pilgrims on earth, showing contentment in God’s promises rather than worldly status.
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:13-16 describes believers as strangers and pilgrims who valued their heavenly home over earthly comfort, teaching humility and contentment in God’s promises.

questions.question: True or False: Hebrews 11 teaches that faith is only about believing in God’s existence, but does not require action or obedience.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:4-8 and many other verses show that faith involves action and obedience, such as Abel's sacrifice and Abraham's journey, not merely belief in God’s existence.

questions.question: True or False: According to Hebrews 11, the faithful always received the promises they hoped for during their lifetime.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:13 and 39 states that the faithful died without receiving the promises but trusted and embraced them from afar, showing faith in God’s future fulfillment.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Hebrews 11:1 defines faith as the substance of things ________, the evidence of things not seen.
questions.correctAnswer: hoped for
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:1 clearly states that faith is the substance of things hoped for and the evidence of things not seen, emphasizing trust in God's promises beyond visible proof.

questions.question: How does Hebrews 11 guide believers in dealing with temptation and perseverance through trials?
options: Faith enabled many to subdue kingdoms, stop lions’ mouths, and endure torture without renouncing God.
Faith guarantees a life without trials or temptation.
Believers should avoid all hardship rather than endure it.
Trials show a lack of faith and should be avoided.
questions.correctAnswer: Faith enabled many to subdue kingdoms, stop lions’ mouths, and endure torture without renouncing God.
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:32-38 describes how faith empowered believers to overcome difficult trials and persecution, encouraging perseverance and trust in God during hardships.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 11, how does faith affect our role in church life and serving others?
options: Faith inspires believers to act righteously and obtain promises, strengthening the community through service and witness.
Faith is a private matter and does not influence service to others.
Serving others is optional and unrelated to faith.
Faith discourages involvement in church life.
questions.correctAnswer: Faith inspires believers to act righteously and obtain promises, strengthening the community through service and witness.
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:33-34 shows that faith leads to righteous acts and victorious service, encouraging believers to contribute actively to church life and support one another.

hard.title: Hebrews Chapter 11 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Hebrews Chapter 11.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 11:3, how were the worlds framed?
questions.correctAnswer: By the word of God
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:3 states that through faith we understand the worlds were framed by the word of God, emphasizing divine creation rather than natural or human means.

questions.question: What is the significance of Abel's sacrifice as described in Hebrews 11:4?
options: It was more excellent than Cain's and testified to his righteousness
It was the first sacrifice offered by man
questions.correctAnswer: It was more excellent than Cain's and testified to his righteousness
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:4 explains that by faith Abel offered a more excellent sacrifice than Cain, which obtained witness that he was righteous, with God testifying of his gifts.

questions.question: Which figure in Hebrews 11 was translated so as not to see death?
questions.correctAnswer: Enoch
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:5 states that by faith Enoch was translated that he should not see death, because he pleased God.

questions.question: True or False: Hebrews 11:6 teaches that faith is necessary to please God and that one must believe He rewards those who seek Him diligently.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:6 clearly states that without faith it is impossible to please God, and that anyone who comes to Him must believe He exists and rewards those who diligently seek Him.

questions.question: What was Noah's response to God's warning about unseen things, according to Hebrews 11:7?
options: He prepared an ark to save his household
He gathered animals without building an ark
questions.correctAnswer: He prepared an ark to save his household
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:7 describes that by faith Noah, warned of things not seen, moved with fear, prepared an ark to save his house, showing obedience and faith.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Abraham obeyed when called to go into a place which he should after receive for an __________.
questions.correctAnswer: inheritance
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:8 states that Abraham obeyed and went out to a place which he should after receive for an inheritance, despite not knowing his destination.

questions.question: What kind of city did Abraham look for, as mentioned in Hebrews 11:10?
options: A city with foundations, built and made by God
A city of gold and silver
questions.correctAnswer: A city with foundations, built and made by God
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:10 reveals Abraham's faith as he looked for a city with foundations whose builder and maker is God, emphasizing a heavenly rather than earthly hope.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 11:11, why was Sarah able to conceive a child despite her old age?
options: Because she judged Him faithful who had promised
questions.correctAnswer: Because she judged Him faithful who had promised
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:11 explains that through faith Sarah received strength to conceive because she considered God faithful to His promise.

questions.question: Which act of faith involved Abraham offering his only begotten son, as described in Hebrews 11:17?
options: He offered up Isaac as a sacrifice
questions.correctAnswer: He offered up Isaac as a sacrifice
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:17 records that by faith Abraham, when tried, offered up Isaac, his only begotten son, demonstrating trust in God's promises.

questions.question: What was Moses' attitude towards being called the son of Pharaoh’s daughter, according to Hebrews 11:24?
options: He refused to be called that son
questions.correctAnswer: He refused to be called that son
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:24 says that by faith Moses refused to be called the son of Pharaoh’s daughter, choosing instead to suffer with God's people.

questions.question: Which event in Hebrews 11:29 demonstrates faith leading to deliverance through a miraculous passage?
options: Passing through the Red Sea on dry land
The fall of the walls of Jericho
The giving of manna in the wilderness
questions.correctAnswer: Passing through the Red Sea on dry land
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:29 recounts that by faith the Israelites passed through the Red Sea as by dry land, while the Egyptians attempting the same were drowned.

questions.question: Who in Hebrews 11:31 is noted for her faith in receiving the spies and not perishing with unbelievers?
questions.correctAnswer: Rahab the harlot
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:31 states that by faith Rahab did not perish with the unbelievers because she received the spies in peace.

questions.question: True or False: Hebrews 11:39-40 explains that those commended for their faith received the promises during their lifetime.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:39-40 clarifies that although these faithful individuals obtained a good report, they did not receive the promises; God provided a better thing for us so they would not be made perfect without us.

questions.question: What literary device is most evident in Hebrews 11’s recounting of various Old Testament figures and their acts of faith?
questions.correctAnswer: Typology
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11 uses typology extensively, presenting Old Testament figures as types and foreshadows of the ultimate faith fulfilled in Christ.

questions.question: In Hebrews 11:19, what theological concept is reflected in Abraham's belief that God was able to raise Isaac from the dead?
questions.correctAnswer: Resurrection
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:19 shows Abraham's faith in God's power to raise Isaac even from the dead, illustrating the doctrine of resurrection central to Christian hope.

theological.title: Hebrews Chapter 11 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Hebrews Chapter 11 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 11:1, how is faith defined in relation to things hoped for and things not seen?
options: Faith is the substance of things hoped for and the evidence of things not seen
Faith is a feeling of certainty about visible things
Faith is trusting only in what can be proven by sight
Faith is an emotional response to hope
questions.correctAnswer: Faith is the substance of things hoped for and the evidence of things not seen
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:1 defines faith as the substance and evidence of what we hope for and do not see. This corresponds with Romans 8:24-25, 2 Corinthians 5:7, John 20:29, and 1 Peter 1:8 which also emphasize faith’s role in trusting unseen promises of God.

questions.question: What is impossible without faith according to Hebrews 11:6?
questions.correctAnswer: To please God
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:6 states that without faith it is impossible to please God. This teaching aligns with Romans 14:23, John 6:29, Ephesians 2:8-9, and James 2:17 emphasizing faith as essential for a right relationship with God.

questions.question: In Hebrews 11:7, Noah's faith is demonstrated by what action?
options: Preparing an ark to save his household
Leading the Israelites out of Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: Preparing an ark to save his household
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:7 highlights Noah’s faith in obeying God's warning and building the ark. This is consistent with Genesis 6:13-22, 2 Peter 2:5, Matthew 24:37-39, and Luke 17:26-27 which affirm Noah’s faith and obedience in the midst of judgment.

questions.question: What was Abraham's response to God's call to go to an unknown place as described in Hebrews 11:8?
options: He obeyed and went without knowing where he was going
He delayed his journey for many years
He refused to leave his homeland
questions.correctAnswer: He obeyed and went without knowing where he was going
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:8 shows Abraham’s faith by obeying God’s call without knowing his destination. This reflects Genesis 12:1-4, Romans 4:18-22, James 2:21, and Galatians 3:7 where Abraham’s faith and obedience are foundational examples.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 11:11, what enabled Sarah to conceive a child despite her old age?
options: Her judgment that God was faithful to His promise
questions.correctAnswer: Her judgment that God was faithful to His promise
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:11 attributes Sarah’s conception to her faith in God’s faithfulness, which aligns with Genesis 18:9-15, Romans 4:19-21, Luke 1:36, and Galatians 4:22-23, all emphasizing trust in God’s power over natural limitations.

questions.question: What does Hebrews 11:13 say about those who died in faith in relation to the promises of God?
options: They did not receive the promises but saw them from afar and confessed they were strangers on earth
They fully received and enjoyed all the promises in their lifetime
They rejected the promises and lived without hope
They only partially believed in the promises
questions.correctAnswer: They did not receive the promises but saw them from afar and confessed they were strangers on earth
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:13 explains that the faithful died without receiving the promises but lived as pilgrims looking forward to them. This concept is consistent with Genesis 23:4, 1 Peter 2:11, Philippians 3:20, and John 14:2-3, highlighting the believer’s temporary status on earth and hope in God’s eternal promises.

questions.question: What did Abraham offer up by faith when he was tested, according to Hebrews 11:17?
questions.correctAnswer: His only begotten son Isaac
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:17 states Abraham offered Isaac by faith as a test. This is also recorded in Genesis 22:1-18, James 2:21-23, Romans 4:20-21, and 1 Peter 1:19-20, demonstrating Abraham’s trust in God’s promise and power to raise the dead.

questions.question: What reason does Hebrews 11:10 give for Abraham's faith regarding the city he looked for?
options: The city has foundations whose builder and maker is God
The city was a wealthy metropolis on earth
The city was promised to him by the king
The city was known and visible to him
questions.correctAnswer: The city has foundations whose builder and maker is God
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:10 describes Abraham's faith as focused on a heavenly city founded and built by God. This relates to Revelation 21:2, John 14:2-3, Philippians 3:20, and Isaiah 65:17, emphasizing the eternal, divine origin of the believer’s true home.

questions.question: How did Moses show faith according to Hebrews 11:24-27?
options: He chose to suffer affliction with God's people rather than enjoy sin's pleasures
He led an army to conquer Egypt
He built the tabernacle with his own hands
He negotiated peace treaties with Pharaoh
questions.correctAnswer: He chose to suffer affliction with God's people rather than enjoy sin's pleasures
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:24-27 recounts Moses refusing to be called Pharaoh's son and choosing suffering with God's people, valuing Christ's reproach. This aligns with Exodus 2:11-25, Numbers 12:3, Acts 7:20-29, and Philippians 3:8 highlighting Moses’ faith and priorities.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 11:29, what did the Israelites do by faith?
options: They passed through the Red Sea as on dry land
They built the temple in Jerusalem
They conquered the Promised Land without battle
They followed Moses to Mount Sinai
questions.correctAnswer: They passed through the Red Sea as on dry land
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:29 highlights the Israelites’ faith in crossing the Red Sea on dry ground, while the Egyptians were drowned. This corresponds with Exodus 14:21-31, Psalm 106:9, 1 Corinthians 10:1-2, and Joshua 3:14-17 which affirm God's miraculous deliverance by faith.

questions.question: What act of faith is Rahab commended for in Hebrews 11:31?
options: Receiving the spies with peace and being spared
Building a place of worship for Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Receiving the spies with peace and being spared
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:31 praises Rahab’s faith in protecting the spies, which saved her from destruction. This is consistent with Joshua 2:1-21, James 2:25, Matthew 1:5, and Hebrews 6:17-20, showing her faith’s role in salvation.

questions.question: What does Hebrews 11:33-34 describe as results of faith among the heroes of old?
options: Subduing kingdoms, working righteousness, obtaining promises, and stopping the mouths of lions
Building temples, writing scriptures, and leading nations
Performing rituals, sacrificing animals, and observing festivals
Living in isolation, performing miracles, and speaking in tongues
questions.correctAnswer: Subduing kingdoms, working righteousness, obtaining promises, and stopping the mouths of lions
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:33-34 enumerates the powerful acts of faith by biblical heroes, corresponding with Daniel 6:16-23, 2 Samuel 5:10, Psalm 18:39, and 1 Kings 17:1-6, illustrating faith’s power to overcome adversity and accomplish God’s purposes.

questions.question: According to Hebrews 11:35, why did some women receive their dead raised to life again, while others endured torture?
questions.correctAnswer: To obtain a better resurrection
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:35 explains that some endured suffering rather than accept deliverance because they sought a better resurrection. This aligns with Luke 20:36, Philippians 3:10-11, John 5:28-29, and 1 Corinthians 15:52-54 emphasizing eternal life’s hope beyond present trials.

questions.question: What does Hebrews 11:40 reveal about God's provision for the faithful who lived before us?
options: God provided something better for us so that they would not be made perfect apart from us
God gave them complete fulfillment of all promises
God excluded us from the covenant
God only honored them and not future believers
questions.correctAnswer: God provided something better for us so that they would not be made perfect apart from us
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:40 teaches that God’s plan includes a better provision culminating in Christ, uniting past and present believers. This corresponds with Romans 8:29-30, Ephesians 2:19-22, 1 Corinthians 12:12-13, and Revelation 21:3-4 highlighting the corporate perfection in Christ’s kingdom.

questions.question: Which of the following best summarizes the reason God is not ashamed to be called the God of those who have faith, according to Hebrews 11:16?
options: Because they desire a better, heavenly country and God has prepared a city for them
Because they perform many religious rituals
Because they build great temples on earth
Because they are wealthy and influential
questions.correctAnswer: Because they desire a better, heavenly country and God has prepared a city for them
questions.explanation: Hebrews 11:16 says God is not ashamed to be called their God because they seek a heavenly country and God prepares a city for them. This theme is echoed in Philippians 3:20, John 14:2, 2 Corinthians 5:1, and Revelation 21:2 emphasizing the hope of eternal dwelling with God.
